facts.text: These are six consolidated appeals arising out of a common judgment and six separate orders of the High Court of Judicature at Patna with certificates under section 66A(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: These are six companysolidated appeals arising out of a companymon judgment and six separate orders of the High Court of Judicature at Patna with certificates under section 66A 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act and they raise companymon questions of la

facts.text: The appeals raise common questions of law regarding whether receipts from Bankura forest lease are capital receipts or agricultural income, and whether receipts from Kharagpur forest are agricultural income.

anchor.surface_text: Whether in the facts and circumstances of the case, the receipts of Bankura forest lease are capital receipts or, in the alternative, companystitute agricultural incom ? Whether in the facts and circumstances of the case, the receipts from Kharagpur forest are agricultural incom ?

facts.text: In the assessment years 1943-44 to 1948-49 the appellant was the owner of the Bankura forest in West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment years 1943-44 to 1948-49 the appellant was the owner of the Bankura forest in West Bengal and the Kharagpur forest in the Monghyr District in Bihar.

facts.text: In the assessment years 1943-44 to 1948-49 the appellant was the owner of the Kharagpur forest in the Monghyr District in Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment years 1943-44 to 1948-49 the appellant was the owner of the Bankura forest in West Bengal and the Kharagpur forest in the Monghyr District in Bihar.

facts.text: The Bankura forest was leased out by auction on short terms for lump sums.

anchor.surface_text: The said Bankura forest was leased out by auction on short terms for lump sums.

facts.text: According to the terms of the lease the lessee was entitled to cut down and remove all sal trees but those which were more than three feet in girth and three feet from the ground and all other jungle trees other than fruit bearing trees and valuable timber trees.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of the lease were number produced, but it was stated that according to the terms of the lease the lessee was entitled to cut down and remove all sal trees but number those which were more than three feet in girth and three feet from the ground and all other jungle trees other than fruit bearing trees and valuable timber trees.

facts.text: The lessee was entitled to cut stumps not higher than five feet over ground.

anchor.surface_text: The lessee was further entitled to cut stumps number higher than five feet over ground.

facts.text: The appellant received income during the assessment years from bamboos, sabai grass and timber from Kharagpur forest.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the Kharagpur forest, the appellant received income during the said assessment years from bamboos, sabai grass and timber.

facts.text: Assessment orders made on 15th March, 1944, 9th March, 1945, 27th March, 1946, 12th March, 1947, 13th March, 1948, and 24th February, 1946 under section 23 of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The officers companycerned with the assessment of the appellant for these assessment years, by assessment orders made under section 23 3  of the Indian Income-tax Act, respectively on 15th March, 1944, 9th March, 1945, 27th March, 1946, 12th March, 1947, 13th March, 1948, and 24th February, 1946,

facts.text: The ITO rejected the appellant's contentions that specific receipts from Bankura and Kharagpur forests were capital receipts or agricultural income.

anchor.surface_text: rejected the companytentions of the appellant that the two sums of Rs. 7,436 and Rs. 11,468 received during the year of account 1349 Fasli, of Rs. 23,581 and Rs. 17,027 received during the year of account 1350 Fasli, of Rs. 20,582 and Rs. 59,514 received during the year of account 1351 Fasli and of Rs. 14,750 and Rs. 98,969 received during the year of account 1352 Fasli, of Rs. 13,836 and Rs. 1,17,173, received during the year of account 1353 Fasli and of Rs. 22,211 and Rs. 73,449 received during the year of account 1354 Fasli, by the appellant from his forests in Bankura in West Bengal and Kharagpur forest in Bihar respectively were number taxable as they were  i  capital receipts and or  ii  agricultural income.

facts.text: Appellant preferred appeals to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax, Patna, or Additional Appellate Assistant Commissioner, which were dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant preferred appeals to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax, Patna, or to the Additional Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax, Patna Range, Patna, as the case may be, against these assessment orders but the said appeals were dismissed and the orders of assessment were companyfirmed.

facts.text: Appeals to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta Bench, were rejected and assessments confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant carried further appeals against these orders of the Appellate Assistant Commissioners to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta Bench, but the Tribunal also rejected the appeals and companyfirmed the assessments.

facts.text: Tribunal refused to refer questions to High Court under section 66(1).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon asked the Tribunal under section 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act for reference to the High Court inter alia of the above questions. The Tribunal, however, held that numberquestion of law arose out of these orders and, accordingly, refused to refer the said questions of law as formulated by the appellant or any other question to the High Court and rejected the appellants said reference applications.

facts.text: High Court directed Tribunal to state case under section 66(2).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to the High Court praying for a direction under section 66 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, requiring the said Tribunal to state a case and the High Court directed the Tribunal to state case inter alia on the said questions of law set out hereinabove.

facts.text: Tribunal submitted statement of case to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal accordingly drew up a statement of case and submitted it ta othe High Court, from which the following facts do appea

facts.text: Bankura forest leased out by auction on short terms for lump sums; lessee can cut specific trees and stumps.

anchor.surface_text: Bankura Forest  West Bengal The forest in this area in block is leased out by auction on short terms for lump sums. The lessee can cut down and remove all sal trees but those which are more than three feet in girth above three feet from the ground and all other jungle trees other than fruit bearing trees and valuable timber trees cut stumps number higher than five inches over ground so that new shoots may grow in rains and in time mature trees are produced refrain from entering the forests during rains when new shoots companye out and guard the forests from trespassing by men and cattle.

facts.text: Kharagpur forest income from bamboos, sabai grass and timber, all grown wild and spontaneously.

anchor.surface_text: Kharagpur Forest  Bihar The income from Kharagpur forest companyes from the three sources, viz.,  i  bamboos,  ii  sabai grass and  iii  timber. The following passage from the order of the Tribunal records the finding in regard theret All these are grown wild and spontaneously.

facts.text: In 1944 a working plan was formulated for felling mature bamboo trees in rotation from sub-divided compartments.

anchor.surface_text: In 1944 a working plan was formulated for felling mature bamboo trees in rotation from sub-divided companypes.

facts.text: No human agency responsible for plantation or growth of bamboos or sabai grass.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be said that any human agency was responsible for either plantation or the growth of the bamboos. The position with regard to sabai grass is more or less the same.

facts.text: Scheme for timber trees: conserving sal and ebony by allowing each tree a circle of 15 feet, clearing jungle.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to timber trees, we find that there was a scheme by which the sal and ebony trees which grow in the forests were companyserved by allowing each tree a circle of 15 feet by clearing the jungle of other trees which fall within this area, thus leaving sufficient space for the growth.

facts.text: Wells sunk for supplying drinking water for cartmen and bullocks, not for watering trees.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt wells were sunk but they were number for the purpose of watering the trees but were for supplying drinking water for the cartmen and bullocks which go into the forests to bring out the timber

facts.text: High Court answered the questions in the negative against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court heard the reference and delivered one companymon judgment as the questions involved therein were companymon and answered the referred questions in the negative and against the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant obtained certificates of fitness for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon applied for and obtained the requisite certificates of fitness for appeal to this Court as aforesaid and hence these appeals.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses the appeals.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that the High Court was right in the decision to which it came and the questions were rightly answered by it against the appellant and these appeals of the appellant must be dismissed with companyts.

arguments.claim: There was no material to hold expenditure of human skill and labour upon the land so as to constitute the income agricultural income under section 2(1)

anchor.surface_text: The High Court decided the referred questions against the appellant mainly on the ground that there was no material on which to hold that there was any expenditure of human skill and labour upon the land so as to constitute the income derived therefrom agricultural income within the meaning of its definition in section 2(1) of the Act.

arguments.claim: Conservation measures like allowing circles around trees, clearing jungle, and conservancy staff do not constitute expenditure of human skill and labour upon the land per Privy Council dictum

anchor.surface_text: The conservation of the forest by allowing each sal and ebony tree a circle of 15 feet and cutting down of the trees and jungles which fell within that circle leaving sufficient space for growth and the employment of conservancy staff maintained to look after the forest were not considered by the Court sufficient in themselves to constitute any expenditure of human skill and labour upon the land so as to fall within the dictum of the Privy Council in Raja Mustafa Ali Khan v. Commissioner of Income-tax.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t the High Court was right in the decision to which it came and the questions were rightly answered by it against the appellant and these appeals of t

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court was right in the decision to which it came

arguments.claim: Principles governing forestry operations on spontaneous growth trees enunciated in CIT v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy apply

anchor.surface_text: We need not repeat here the principles which govern the decision of cases like these where forestry operations are performed by the assessee in regard to forest trees of spontaneous growth. They have been enunciated by us in the judgment just delivered in Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy.

arguments.claim: For spontaneous growth forest trees with no basic agricultural operations on soil by assessee, there is no cultivation; only subsequent operations which do not qualify as agriculture unless integrated with basic operations

anchor.surface_text: Suffice it to say that in regard to the forest trees of spontaneous growth, which grow on the soil unaided by any human skill and labour and where no basic operations in agriculture are performed upon the soil itself by the assessee, there is no cultivation of the soil at all. The only operations which are performed by the assessee are subsequent operations...

arguments.claim: Operations performed by assessee had nothing in common with basic agricultural operations and did not convert spontaneous growth forest produce into agricultural produce

anchor.surface_text: The operations which were performed by the assessee in the cases before us had nothing in common with the basic agricultural operations and did not have the effect of converting the forest produce which was of spontaneous growth into produce raised upon the land by agriculture within the connotation of that term as laid down by us in the decision referred to above.

holdings.text: The receipts from Bankura forest lease are neither capital receipts nor agricultural income
